reviewText: I have a very dim memory of seeing this show as a child and I'm into aviation so I was curious to see this show again. Despite the poor video quality (watchable, but not great) the show has a real appeal. Somehow the dialogue seems a cut above the average. For instance, one character will hypothesize some goofy theory to explain something, and just as you're saying "Come'on" another character in the show will pipe up "Are you nuts?".Kenneth Tobey is excellent, as always, and the supporting cast is perfectly fine although I don't recognize any of them. Shows from this era have three unique things going for them:* 30-minute dramas are now extinct for some reason.* There's always a technology angle to the stories (i.e. scuba gear on SeaHunt).* The characters are real people, making a living doing something they love.I find all this a refreshing change from modern TV. Let's hope somebody dredges up a few more of these episodes. FYI, the 8 episodes are picked from across the three seasons of the show so you get to see several models of Bell helicopters.
summary: It's always good to see Kenneth Tobey

reviewText: Boy do the memories of childhood flood back when this was on telly. Back in the day we kids just knew the stars as just two guys in a helicopter, but now I learn its Kenneth Tobey from a handful of great sci fi movies of the fifties. I hope the whole series is made available very soon as I can hardly wait to watch the lot. This is a must for fans of Sea hunt,  Ripcord, style shows of the late fifties. The rest of you? Well you just would be wasting your time and cash to be truthful. Ah, memories are made of things like this.Please remember the age of these shows and do not expect too much from them, after all we were ever so young back then.
summary: it's the two guys in the hellicopter

reviewText: A wonderful Golden Age television series that was filmed by Desilu Studios (yes, that was under the guidance of the ever forward-thinking partnership of Lucy Ball and Desi Arnaz) with the backing of CBS-TV Films although it was a syndicated show, not a CBS program. Some intelligent episodes although a few are pretty silly by today's standards. Many rising stars of the era, such as Robert Vaughn, James Coburn, and Mike Connors, to name a few, appear. Tobey and Hill had great chemistry, with Chuck as a Korean War chopper vet who went into business with a young, upcoming chopper pilot in the decade after the war--the duo are modeled after the L.A.-area based National Helicopter Service which did all the flying appearing in the episodes. Ironic that award-winning "M*A*S*H" film director Robert Altman directed many WB episodes. When it came time for him to film "M*A*S*H" in 1969, he contacted National Helicopters (the WB aircraft suppliers) and the Bells flew again in front of the cameras. Sadly, there is only one high-quality  collection of this series in a private collector's archive and unlikely to be converted to video anytime in the near future. Also, stories abound that some episodes are lost. The San Fernando Valley airport used as Chuck and P.T.'s base of operations no longer exists; it is now a large trucking facility (sadly, the vanishing rate of America's small airports is far more accelerated today). The surrounding landscape, familiar to T.V. viewers of this series, is nearly unrecognizable today thanks to SoCal suburban sprawl. Yuck! (Aside: The tarnished Golden State these days.) There is a modest Baby Boomer fan following of this show and you can fine two "reenactors", billing their air show as "The New Whirlybirds", flying a restored Bell chopper to various air shows in the Midwest and elsewhere, notably the annual Rotor Fest at the National Helicopter Museum in West Chester, Pennsylvania USA.

reviewText: For those of you who grew up on those great Black and White TV Shows like I did, add Whirlybirds to your list.. It's great.. Wonderful photography of those 1950's Southern CAlifornia sights. nice stories, and nice people... Things we all wish were around these days... Desilu produced it and even the Bell Ranger (not jet ranger pre-jet days) gets a credit...My kids who were home from collage when I got it loved it foo.. it's great family entertainment and I wish Amazon would get more of those great TV shows like Hawaiian Eye,Surfside 6, and 77 Sunset Strip, before the only thing available on DVD are those reality shows that have nothing to do with reality. Glad we got this show.. Thanks for that Amazon

reviewText: It arrived in excellent condition and was professionally shipped.I got exactly what I expected from the seller and would recommend that anyone interested in this series should attempt to obtain this DVD.The quality of the episodes is not all that good, but I believe that the folks who produced the video were not given the best quality prints from their suppliers.At least I got to watch one of my favorite TV shows from when I was a kid under 10 years of age and I was happy to view them once again, after almost 50 years of not seeing them.

reviewText: All 60 episodes are available - You have to look.  (wikipedia says there are 111 episodes.)Whirlybirds is almost as good as Sea Hunt!Kenneth Tobey is a very enjoyable actor. He frequently plays a regular, standup guy, doing his job.Kenneth Tony was made famous in the masterpiece motion picture "The Thing from another world" made in the 1950s (do not confuse this movie with the terrible remake of the 1980s).As a pilot, I can tell you that the helicopter flying depicted in this series is a little different than the real world today. In Whirlybirds there is a lot of low-flying and landing where you feel like it. Those stunts would cost to your pilots license (or worse) very quickly today.All in all a very enjoyable television program. I guess after 60 episodes you run out of dramatic things you can do with a helicopter.
summary: All 60 episodes are available - Almost as good as Sea Hunt.
